Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Mid-crustal Strain during Extension: A Field-based Investigation of Rheological Transitions, Doming, and Vertical Coupling
Award.AbstractNarration:
The manner in which the Earths crust responds to tectonic and gravitational forces depends on the strength distribution of crustal rocks. It has been widely proposed that in certain settings, rocks in the lower half of the crust may be sufficiently weak that they flow laterally in response to pressure differences induced by topographic gradients. Such behavior has important implications for many processes in the continental crust, for example, the growth of mountain plateaus, formation of basins and continental shelves, and seismicity within the continents. These models, however, need to be rigorously tested through better field-based investigations. The Pioneer Mountains of Idaho, where these PIs will focus their study, expose rocks that may represent a boundary zone between strong rocks and underlying weaker flowing rocks, and if so will provide an excellent opportunity to test models that involve flow of weak lower crustal rocks. Better field documentation of the vertical changes in rocks strength will provide us with a more comprehensive view of continental deformation.

Many recent models of crustal deformation feature a middle to lower crust that is sufficiently weak that it decouples and flows in response to lateral pressure gradients. Such flow has profound implications for several aspects of crustal deformation. Many of the current models for weak decoupled middle to lower crustal flow, however, are derived from indirect observation and the extent to which model rheological layers are represented in the rock record is unclear. Preliminary work shows that the Pioneer core complex in Idaho contains a midcrustal section exposing a decoupling boundary, which presents an opportunity to test models of weak and decoupled flow. In this project the PIs with test models of variable decoupling will be tested through documentation of the strain history in the midcrustal rocks through field-based structural and AMS analysis, combined with U-Pb geochronology, and Ar/Ar thermochronology. Together these data will allow us to compare in detail, the kinematic and strain histories at the various structural levels and investigate the relationships between the mid-crustal rheological layering, domes, and upper crustal extension.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The manner in which the Earths crust responds to tectonic and gravitational forces depends on the strength distribution of crustal rocks. It has been widely proposed that in certain settings, rocks in the lower half of the crust may be sufficiently weak that they decouple from overlying rocks and flow laterally in response to pressure gradients, independent of tectonic forces. Such behavior has important implications for many processes in the continental crust, for example, the growth of mountain plateaus, formation of basins and continental shelves, and seismicity within the continents. In areas where the continental crust is extending, normal faults may remove several kilometers of upper crust. Removal of this material may be compensated by inward flow of weak decoupled lower/middle crust from adjacent unextended regions.

Many of the current models for weak decoupled middle to lower crustal flow are derived from indirect observations and the extent to which model rheological layers are represented in the rock record is unclear. These models need to be rigorously tested through better field-based investigations. We have used exposures in the Pioneer Mtns. of south-central Idaho, as a natural laboratory to investigate the behavior of the hot, weak middle crust to test existing models that involve decoupling. In this area, igneous and metamorphic rocks originally at depths greater than 12-15 km are faulted against rocks that were never buried more than 3-4 km. The deeper package of rocks exposes a 5-6 km thick section of rock, providing the range of depth exposures necessary for testing these models. These rocks form an elongate dome; the processes associated with these types of domes are central to understanding of the behavior of the middle crust as they may form from horizontal shortening, low buoyancy (diapirism), or compensatory inflow. In our study, we have employed field mapping, a variety of structural techniques, and multiple isotopic dating techniques.

Our work has revealed that the deep-level rocks have complex fabrics patterns recording multiple movement directions. In some places, movement directions correlate with depth. However, movement directions also vary laterally and do not correlate with depth across the entire area. Our dating of the rock fabrics formed from these different motions indicates that much of strain recorded in these rocks formed over a geologically short time interval of only 2-3 m.y., between about 49-48 and 46 Ma.

The integration of our mapping, structural analysis, and dating indicates that, in this area, no end-member models previously proposed for other geologically similar areas explains all of our data. For example, in parts of our study area, strain was clearly coupled and conforms to many coupled models that propose that strain in the middle crust is concentrated in ductile shear zones that are connected with brittle faults at higher levels, with both parts having the same movement directions. Other areas, however, record upward motion of the deeper rocks relative to shallower rocks, with motion at a high-angle to the regional WNW-ESE extension direction recorded by faults at higher levels; this strain pattern is consistent with a model where the deeper rocks were decoupled and flowed upward and inward compensating for the removal of overlying rocks by extensional faulting.
